title: How to Prevent Mold on a Deck

steps.headline: Understand what causes mold to grow on a deck so you can avoid deck mold.
Build your deck, and keep in mind that you're preventing deck mold from occurring.
Sweep regularly to remove mold spores from a deck.
steps.description: Sweeping will also remove food needed for the spores to grow, such as pollen or dirt, as well as any dormant spores.

steps.headline: Regularly power wash your deck with a strong sprayer to prevent deck mold spores.

text:
Understand what causes mold to grow on a deck so you can avoid deck mold. Mold thrives in dampness. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Mold needs food, such as pollen and dirt, to survive. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Mold enjoys temperate weather, although mold spores can stay dormant through extreme weather situations, such as drought or frost. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Mold likes shady areas away from direct sun. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-1Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Build your deck, and keep in mind that you're preventing deck mold from occurring. Build with a composite material that has mold inhibitors in its construction. Wood is very agreeable to mold spores, and decks built out of wood often suffer from mold problems. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Ultraviolet rays from sunlight will kill mold spores, so you may want to build a deck where there is adequate sunlight. You may also want to cut back as many trees around the deck area as possible. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Slope the deck away from the house so that it drains well. Slope should be 1/8 inch (.32 cm) for every 8 feet (2.44 m) of deck. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Gap the decking material at least 1/8 inch (.32 cm) for adequate draining. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Prevent-Mold-on-a-Deck-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sweep regularly to remove mold spores from a deck. Sweeping will also remove food needed for the spores to grow, such as pollen or dirt, as well as any dormant spores. Regularly power wash your deck with a strong sprayer to prevent deck mold spores.
